Cold is the heart, extinct the vital spark</br>That kindles not to flame at Harold's muse,</br>The mental vision too, how surely dark,</br>Which, as the anxious wanderer it pursues,</br>Sees not a noble heart, that fain would choose</br>The course to heaven, could that course be found,</br>And since on earth, it nothing fears to lose,</br>Would joy to press that blest ethereal ground</br>Where peace and truth and life, and friends abound.

I "deem not Harold's breast, a breast of steel;"</br>(Steel is the heart that could the thought conceive)</br>But warm, affectionate, and quick to feel;</br>Eager in joy, yet not unwont to grieve:</br>And sorely do I view his vessel leave,</br>Like erring bark of card and chart bereft,</br>The shore to which his soul would love to cleave.</br>Would Harold I could make thee know full oft,</br>That leaving thus the helm, the land thou seek'st is lost.

Is Harold satiated with worldly joy?</br>Leaves he his home and lands without a sigh?</br>'Tis half the way to heaven — Oh then employ</br>That blessed freedom of thy soul, to fly</br>To him, who ever gracious, ever nigh,</br>Demands the heart, that breaks the world's hard chain</br>If early freed, tho' by satiety;</br>Vast is the privilege that man may gain,</br>Who early foils the foe, may well the prize obtain.

Thou lovest nature with a filial zeal,</br>Can'st fly mankind, to brood with her apart?</br>Unutterable sure that inward feel</br>When swells the soul, and heaves the lab'ring heart,</br>With yearning throes, which nothing can impart</br>But nature's majesty, remote from man</br>In kindred raptures, I have borne my part,</br>The Pyrenean horrors lov'd to scan,</br>And from the crest of Alps peruse the mighty plan.

"'Tis ecstasy" to muse o'er flood and fell,</br>To slowly trace the forests shady scene</br>Where things, that own not man's dominion dwell,</br>"And mortal foot hath ne'er or rarely been:</br>To climb the trackless mountain all unseen,</br>With the wild flock, that never needs a fold,</br>Alone o'er steeps and foaming falls to lean.</br>THIS is not solitude, 'tis but to hold</br>Converse with nature's charms, and see her stores unroll'd."

Forget we not the artist in the art,</br>Nor overlook the giver in the grace:</br>Say what is nature but the little part</br>Which man's imperfect vision can embrace</br>Of the stupendous whole, that fills all space,</br>The work of him by whom all space is bound?</br>Shall Raphael's pencil, Raphael's self efface;</br>Shall Handel's self be lost in Handel's sound?</br>And shall not nature's God, in nature's works be found?

But Harold through sin's labyrinth has run,</br>Nor made atonement when he did amiss;</br>And does the memory of that evil done</br>Disturb his spirit, and obscure his bliss?</br>'Tis just — 'tis Harold's due — yet let not this</br>Press heavier on the heart than heaven ordains;</br>What mortal lives not guilty or remiss?</br>What heart that hath not felt remorse's pains?</br>What human soul is pure, but mark'd by some sad stains?

And can this helpless thing, pollute, debas'd,</br>Its own disfigur'd nature e'er reform?</br>Say, can the sculptured marble once defac'd,</br>Restore its lineament, renew its form?</br>That can the sculptor's hand alone perform,</br>Else must the marr'd and mutilated stone</br>For ever be imperfect and deform'd;</br>So man may sin and wail, but not atone,</br>That restorative power belongs to God alone.

Yet is atonement made — creation's Lord</br>Deserts not thus the work his skill devis'd</br>Man not his creature only, but his ward;</br>Too dearly his Maker's eye is priz'd,</br>Than thus to lie abandon'd and despis'd;</br>Atonement is the Almighty's richest dole,</br>And ever in the mystic plan compris'd,</br>To mend the foul debasement of the soul,</br>Restore God's likeness lost, and make his image whole.

Oh!  "If as holiest men have deem'd there be</br>A land of souls beyond death's sable shore,"</br>How would quick-hearted Harold burn to see</br>The much-lov'd objects of his life once more,</br>And nature's new sublimities explore</br>In better worlds!  Ah!  Harold, I conjure</br>Speak not in ifs to those whom God has taught,</br>If ought on earth, — that blessed truth is sure,</br>All-gracious God, to quiet human thought,</br>Hath pledg'd his sacred word, and demonstration wrought.

Did Babylon in truth by Cyrus fall?</br>Is't true that Persia stain'd the Grecian land?</br>Did Philip's son the Persian host enthrall?</br>Or Caesar's legions press the British strand?</br>Fell Palestine by Titus' sword and brand:</br>Can Harold to those facts his faith entrust?</br>Then let him humbly learn, and understand</br>That Christ is risen from the dead, the first</br>Dear pledge to mortal frames yet mouldering in the dust.

But Harold will not look beyond the tomb,</br>And thinks he may not hope for rest before;</br>Fie, Harold, fie!  unconscious of thy doom,</br>The nature of thy soul thou know'st not more,</br>Nor know'st thy lofty mind, which loves to soar!</br>Thy glowing spirit, and thy thought sublime,</br>Are foreign on this flat and naked shore;</br>And languish for their own celestial clime</br>Far in the bounds of space, beyond the bounds of time.

Then must thou surely live, and of that life</br>Ages on ages shall no part exhaust,</br>But with renew'd existence ever rise</br>No more in dark uncertainty be lost,</br>When once that seeming barrier is cross'd</br>The birth of mortals to immortal day,</br>Oh!  let not then this precious hour be lost,</br>But humbly turn to him, who points the way</br>To ever-daring youth, from infinite decay.

Such, such the prospect!  such the glorious boon,</br>The last great end in heaven's supreme design;</br>Think not thy cloud continues, for soon</br>Must truth break in upon a soul like thine,</br>Yearning unconscious for the light divine.</br>Oh!  hear the gracious word to thee addressed,</br>By him thy Lord, Almighty, and benign,</br>"Come unto me, all ye by care oppressed,</br>Come to my open arms, and I will give you rest."

Would thou hadst lov'd through Judah's coasts to stray,</br>Would Sion Hill, Parnassus' love might share,</br>What joy to hear the muses potent lay,</br>The sacred horrors of that land declare,</br>And all that holy scene engage her care,</br>Where poet's harp, with Homer's skill, was strung,</br>Where heavenly wisdom pour'd her treasures rare,</br>Long, long ere Athens' woke to Solon's tongue,</br>And truth-inspir'd seers of after ages sung.

But thanks for that we have, and for the more</br>Thy muse doth bid the listening ear attend;</br>Nor vainly bid, those whom she charm'd before,</br>Oh!  let not then his humble verse offend.</br>Her skill can judge the speaking of a friend,</br>Nor zeal presumptuous prompts the cautious strain,</br>But christian love, that would to all extend</br>The cloudless ray and steady calm which reign</br>Where evangelic truths their empire due maintain.</br>
